data.title: MonoGame 3.5 - "AllowUserResizing/AllowAltF4 = false" has no effect using the UAP template
Dispose XAudio source voices before disposing the XAudio master voice.
data.body:
When tracking down some intermittent crashes on shutdown which seemed to be related to XAudio, I found that with a debug build of MonoGame and the Windows SDK installed I would see an "XAUDIO2: ERROR: The voice still has 1 senders" error output by my program on shutdown.

Looking into it further I found:

1) Reports of crashes if the mastering voice isn't destroyed properly before the device is destroyed.
2) https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/desktop/hh405048(v=vs.85).aspx documenting that source voices must be destroyed before the mastering voice can be.

This PR causes sound effect instances to be disposed (which disposes their source voice) on PlatformShutdown of SoundEffect, before the MasteringVoice is disposed, and stops the XAudio error from being output on shutdown. I believe this also fixes an intermittent crash problem on shutdown but it's harder to tell.

I think so long as you didn't shut down while playing audio, you'd only have seen this problem if you were using pooled SoundEffectInstances, but otherwise it should have shown up consistently.

data.title: Improved accuracy of fixed time step
data.body:
This is in response to issue #4202. I can't say that it will resolve the issue, but it should definitely at least improve things a little. (UPDATE: @bousquetm confirmed that there was a big improvement with my changes, so I think it's now fair to say that this resolves #4202)

In summary, this PR tries to better consider the inaccuracy of "Sleep" and use it more conservatively to try and avoid overshooting the desired update time. The side effect of this is that there'll be some CPU spinning, but the CPU usage increase should be minimal.

For Windows platforms (except for WinRT), it now considers the timer resolution when sleeping. It will try to sleep as long as possible without overshooting, and then spin the CPU for the remainder. My tests have shown this to be very accurate, and in theory it should never actually overshoot due to oversleeping.

I couldn't use this trick on other platforms though. So for other platforms, it instead only tries to sleep when the next update time is still at least 1ms away, otherwise it will spin the CPU for the remainder. Also, to further reduce the chance of overshooting, it will only perform a "Sleep(1)" each time it does sleep.

Lastly, @nkast also pointed out that `Task.Delay` (used by WinRT in place of `Thread.Sleep`) was generating garbage. So I've changed it to use `Monitor.Wait` instead, which should be just as accurate without the garbage generation. I wasn't able to properly test this though with a Windows Store app.

While I was able to test all of the 3 methods on my Windows 7 machine and prove they at least work on that platform, I wasn't able to test any of this on any other platforms. WinRT in particular probably needs a good test as it's now using `Monitor.Wait` to sleep. The other platforms should be ok though as the change was much less significant, but it would be great if someone could test them also.

**UPDATE (30-Oct):**
After some discussion, it was decided that only the Windows platform would attempt to sleep when using fixed time step because we can still maintain timing accuracy. For all other platforms we couldn't guarantee accuracy when sleeping though, so it now spins the CPU instead (which is what XNA seems to do as well). And to compensate for this, the `Game.InactiveSleepTime` feature from XNA (https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/microsoft.xna.framework.game.inactivesleeptime.aspx) was also implemented so that sleeping would be performed when the game window is inactive.

data.title: Fixes floating point precision edge case error with Lerp
data.body:
According to wikipedia, the current implementation of MathHelper.Lerp suffers from a floating point precision issue.
(https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear_interpolation#Programming_language_support)

There's also a relevant SO discussion on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/4353525/floating-point-linear-interpolation#answer-23716956

Admittedly an edge case, but the fix seems to have negligible performance impact.

I couldn't run the test suite, so I created a simple console app to showcase the issue (and to see if the perf was impacted):
https://gist.github.com/hede/66914c6ebafd5a6c1c03

P.S. Why does Vector2.Lerp call MathHelper.Lerp separately on X and Y? Is it perf? We have the Vector operator overloads in place. Implementing it with vector operations might be easier to parse mentally IMHO

data.title: Windows DirectX: WinFormsGameWindow.UpdateWindows generating garbage
data.body:
I've recently been profiling my game a bit (using CLRProfiler) to try and find code generating excess garbage, and I came across the following from MonoGame (this is from the heap allocation graph):
![profile1](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5249498/10633916/b1f0a33a-7820-11e5-8eff-3c8e69372028.png)
I took a closer look at the method in question and found that there was some LINQ being used which seemed to be the culprit:

``` C#
foreach (var window in _allWindows.Where(w => w.Game == Game))
    window.UpdateMouseState();
```

So I changed it to the following and that seemed to clean it up:

``` C#
foreach (var window in _allWindows)
    if (window.Game == Game)
        window.UpdateMouseState();
```

![profile2](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5249498/10634004/4c46f218-7821-11e5-9358-4133ba7a68ee.png)
I looked at UpdateMouseState also, but these allocations seemed to be coming from the .NET Framework itself so I assume there's not much that can be done about that.

If I'm correct about this, I'm more than happy to submit a PR. I just thought I'd raise an issue first to see what others thought as I'm fairly new to reducing garbage generation (my C# experience so far was mainly in business software dev).

data.title: Fix: Asset was built multiple times with same settings.
data.body:
This PR solves two problems:
- _Problem 1: "An asset is built multiple times, even though the processor parameters are identical."_
  When PipelineBuildEvents are compared, the method PipelineBuildEvents.AreParametersEqual assumes that the same parameters are stored in both dictionaries. This is not true in practice.
  Example: One PipelineBuildEvent stores the parameter ("ColorKeyEnabled", true). The second PipelineBuildEvent does not have a matching entry. The two PipelineBuildEvents might still be equivalent. We need to compare the parameter with the default value of the content processor.
- _Problem 2: "The order of the assets in the content project should not matter, but it does matter."_
  Example: ModelA, ModelB, TextureC are included in the content project. Both models reference TextureC.
  Currently when the order in the content project is ModelA, ModelB, TextureC, the TextureC is output as "Texture_0.xnb" and "Texture.xnb". If the order is TextureC, ModelA, ModelB, the output is only "Texture.xnb", which is in in my opinion the correct result.
  To solve the problem, all asset that need to be registered as PipelineBuildEvents before building any assets. Then it is possible to correctly resolve external references.

data.title: Removed GamePadThumbSticks.Gate property
data.body:
Closes #4170

This PR removes the superfluous `GamePadThumbSticks.Gate` property as discussed in issue #4170. This property did not exist in XNA, and it's default setting (i.e. round gate type) only matched XNA behaviour when using a circular dead zone.

I've now changed clamping of thumbstick values to be in line with XNA. From my tests and observations, XNA applies circular clamping when using a circular dead zone (i.e. clamps the vector length to 1). In all other cases (including the public constructor), it applies square clamping (i.e. clamps the vector within bounds [-1,-1]..[1,1]).

I've also added some unit tests for the public constructor to test that values are being clamped as expected (which fail with the previous MonoGame code due to the incorrect default clamping).

data.title: Fixed #4192 "Copy Task does not support copying directories" UWP build issue
Implemented DrawInstancedPrimitives(), SetVertexBuffers() and improved input layout caching for DirectX.
data.body:
This PR adds the DirectX implementation for **DrawInstancedPrimitives** and **SetVertexBuffers**. The hashing and caching of vertex input layouts is also fixed/improved.

Before writing this code, we have reviewed the related issues for these topics:
- GraphicsDevice.DrawInstancedPrimitives API not yet implemented. #913
- GraphicsDevice.SetVertexBuffers API is not yet implemented #914
- Implemented GraphicsDevice.SetVertexBuffers(...) #3276

This implementation is used successfully in the DigitalRune Engine for mesh instancing and morph target animation. We have also added some simple unit tests.

There is one important change regarding the vertex attribute semantics **SV_Position** and **POSITION** in shaders:
The recommended semantic for the vertex input element which describes the vertex position is **POSITION**. However, the XNA stock effects use **SV_Position**. This is allowed in DirectX but it is better to use **SV_Position** ("system-value position") only for the vertex shader output and pixel shader input. 
This is important when using morph targets. Each morph target mesh has a **POSITION0** element. At runtime the morph target vertex streams are matched and combined to a single input layout with **POSITION0/1/2/3**. This is not possible with **SV_Position** because **SV_Position1/2/3** is not a valid semantic.
Therefore, we have changed the C# code and shaders to use **POSITION** for vertex inputs. 
The new code contains a fallback to handle shaders with **SV_Position**, but we recommend to only use **POSITION** for vertex shader input for all future MonoGame shaders.

The vertex input type for BLENDINDICES has been changed from int4 to uint4. This prevents SharpDX warnings when run on debug device. (The problem is that the MonoGame content pipeline outputs Byte4 for BLENDINDICES. MonoGame does not have a signed integer format that matches int4.)

This PR also fixes a minor bug in the GraphicsDevice OpenGL code: The flag **_vertexBufferDirty** was never reset to false.
